title: 110_s1684
content: The "Return of Talent Act" is a program under the Immigration and Nationality Act that allows for temporary absence of individuals participating in the return of talent program. The Return of Talent Program, established by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Secretary of State, allows eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship for up to 24 months to contribute to post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction. Eligible aliens must meet special immigrant criteria, and their family members can accompany them. The Return of Talent Program allows eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship for up to 24 months to contribute to post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction. The Secretary of Homeland Security may extend the period if necessary. Immigrants participating in the program and their family members are considered physically present in the US for naturalization purposes. The Return of Talent Program allows eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship for up to 24 months to contribute to post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction. The Secretary of Homeland Security oversees and enforces the continuous residency requirements for naturalization purposes. SEC. 3. ELIGIBLE IMMIGRANTS. 317A. Temporary absence of persons participating in the Return of Talent Program. Section 101(a)(27) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category (N) for immigrants who are lawful permanent residents in the U.S., willing to contribute to post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction in their home country, subject to approval by the Secretaries of State and Homeland Security. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category for immigrants who are willing to contribute to post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction in their home country, subject to approval by the Secretaries of State and Homeland Security. Eligibility criteria include being a citizen of a country where the US Armed Forces have been engaged in combat or peacekeeping operations, where UN peacekeeping operations were initiated, or where funding was received from the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category for immigrants willing to contribute to post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction in their home country, subject to approval by the Secretaries of State and Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The report should detail the countries of citizenship of participants in the Return of Talent Program, post-conflict or natural disaster reconstruction efforts aided by the program, and any other relevant information. Additionally, within 6 months of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to issue regulations to implement the Act and its amendments. Authorization of appropriations for the Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services for fiscal year 2008 is provided in this Act.
